posts.cooked:
We are trying to figure out why our elevator is going very slowly, and we have found that our elevator motors are not applying a voltage higher than about 4 volts (or lower than -4 volts) even when they are commanded to go at higher voltages (including 12 V). We have two Falcon 500s which are mechanically linked with one as a leader and the other as a follower and are only commanding voltage on the leader motor. This is what voltage looks like when commanding voltage based on joystick input: image 1459×883 74.7 KB (Here the red line represents the joystick input and the motors are being commanded to go 12 times the voltage. We are not hitting either our stator current or our supply current limit. If anybody has any idea what is going on and/or how we could fix it that would be extremely helpful.

image 1459×883 74.7 KB

image 1459×883 74.7 KB

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: Have you tried giving it more voltage in Phoenix tuner? What happens then? If you config factory defaults and it still isn’t working in Phoenix tuner then it’s probably a problem with the motor or how it’s wired.

I would try manually controlling the motors in Phoenix tuner. I would also check the supply voltage of the falcons because they won’t give more than that. To ensure you’re not hitting current limits you could briefly turn them off to see if it makes a difference, are you sure the motors aren’t fighting each other? After checking all this a bunch of times for our team it still seemed like one of our motors was getting current limited but it was resolved when we reinstalled the firmware on it.

Strflightmight:

Have you tried giving it more voltage in Phoenix tuner? What happens then? If you config factory defaults and it still isn’t working in Phoenix tuner then it’s probably a problem with the motor or how it’s wired.

Wispy:

I would try manually controlling the motors in Phoenix tuner. I would also check the supply voltage of the falcons because they won’t give more than that. To ensure you’re not hitting current limits you could briefly turn them off to see if it makes a difference, are you sure the motors aren’t fighting each other? After checking all this a bunch of times for our team it still seemed like one of our motors was getting current limited but it was resolved when we reinstalled the firmware on it.

Yes, I tried running them in Phoenix Tuner, and experienced the same problem, even after resetting settings to factory. Supply voltage is not the problem because if supply voltage was that low the robot would be browning out. Is the next step really just replacing the motors? We do have spares but it would be a pain to take apart our gearboxes.

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: I’d try checking the wiring first. Maybe try just wiring one at a time and seeing what happens. It could also be a problem with the other components (power distribution board / Rio)

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: Do you have a hoot log of when this happens? Do you also have a link to your code on GitHub?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.cooked: Can you also send the full config for the motors? You arent by any chance setting the peak forward or reverse voltages?
